articles.headline: Michael Cohen Has Said He Would Take a Bullet for Trump. Maybe Not Anymore.
articles.snippet: Roger Stone says Mr. Trump has long treated Mr. Cohen, his lawyer and fixer, “like garbage.” Now he could end up cooperating in a criminal investigation against Mr. Trump.
articles.abstract: Roger Stone says Mr. Trump has long treated Mr. Cohen, his lawyer and fixer, “like garbage.” Now he could end up cooperating in a criminal investigation against Mr. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, a joke among Trump Tower employees was that the boss was like Manhattan’s First Avenue, where the traffic goes only one way.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Sharon LaFraniere and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: U.S. Investigating AT&T and Verizon Over Wireless Collusion Claim
articles.snippet: Complaints to the Justice Department allege that the companies and a standards group worked together to restrict eSIM technology, a cardless way to easily switch carriers.
articles.abstract: Complaints to the Justice Department allege that the companies and a standards group worked together to restrict eSIM technology, a cardless way to easily switch carriers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has opened an antitrust investigation into potential coordination by AT&T, Verizon and a telecommunications standards organization to hinder consumers from easily switching wireless carriers, according to six people with knowledge of the inquiry.

articles.headline: Electric Scooters Are Causing Havoc. This Man Is Shrugging It Off.
articles.snippet: Travis VanderZanden, chief executive of electric scooter start-up Bird, is unperturbed by how San Francisco and other cities are in an uproar over the dockless vehicles.
articles.abstract: Travis VanderZanden, chief executive of electric scooter start-up Bird, is unperturbed by how San Francisco and other cities are in an uproar over the dockless vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: VENICE, Calif. — Travis VanderZanden, the chief executive of electric scooter company Bird Rides, surveyed the new indoor park at his office one morning this week.
articles.byline: By Nellie Bowles and David Streitfeld

articles.headline: Pressure to Release Comey Memos May Have Backfired on G.O.P.
articles.snippet: The deputy attorney general’s decision to release the memos did little to help Republicans undermine the credibility of James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director.
articles.abstract: The deputy attorney general’s decision to release the memos did little to help Republicans undermine the credibility of James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For days, top Republicans in Congress demanded the release of James B. Comey’s memos about President Trump, threatening Rod J. Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general, with a subpoena if he failed to share the highly anticipated documents written by the former F.B.I. director.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: Hundreds of Immigrant Children Have Been Taken From Parents at U.S. Border
articles.snippet: The Trump administration says it separates immigrant families only when necessary to protect the child. But the government’s own figures show this has happened in more than 700 cases.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration says it separates immigrant families only when necessary to protect the child. But the government’s own figures show this has happened in more than 700 cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Feb. 20, a young woman named Mirian arrived at the Texas border carrying her 18-month-old son. They had fled their home in Honduras through a cloud of tear gas, she told border agents, and needed protection from the political violence there.

articles.headline: Is Facebook’s Campbell Brown a Force to Be Reckoned With? Or Is She Fake News?
articles.snippet: As Facebook’s head of news partnerships, Ms. Brown, a former CNN and NBC anchor, is emerging as a surprisingly adept negotiator for her publishing vision at the social network.
articles.abstract: As Facebook’s head of news partnerships, Ms. Brown, a former CNN and NBC anchor, is emerging as a surprisingly adept negotiator for her publishing vision at the social network.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was another terrible day for Facebook and the company had dispatched Campbell Brown, its head of news partnerships, to do some damage control.

articles.headline: With a Glance Backward, Brooks Brothers Looks to the Future
articles.snippet: The reinvention of the 200-year-old American brand by its brash Italian owner, Claudio Del Vecchio, has meant staying true to its past.
articles.abstract: The reinvention of the 200-year-old American brand by its brash Italian owner, Claudio Del Vecchio, has meant staying true to its past.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early 2002, just a few months after he officially took over as the new owner and chief executive officer of Brooks Brothers, Claudio Del Vecchio confronted the reality that the classic American retailer had largely lost its way.

articles.headline: Where Countries Are Tinderboxes and Facebook Is a Match
articles.snippet: False rumors set Buddhist against Muslim in Sri Lanka, the most recent in a global spate of violence fanned by social media.
articles.abstract: False rumors set Buddhist against Muslim in Sri Lanka, the most recent in a global spate of violence fanned by social media.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEDAMAHANUWARA, Sri Lanka — Past the end of a remote mountain road, down a rutted dirt track, in a concrete house that lacked running water but bristled with smartphones, 13 members of an extended family were glued to Facebook. And they were furious.
articles.byline: By Amanda Taub and Max Fisher

articles.headline: Fearing Chaos, National Democrats Plunge Into Midterm Primary Fights
articles.snippet: Democratic leaders are intervening aggressively in California, where the state’s unusual voting system could undercut their chances in crowded congressional races.
articles.abstract: Democratic leaders are intervening aggressively in California, where the state’s unusual voting system could undercut their chances in crowded congressional races.
articles.lead_paragraph: FULLERTON, Calif. — The Democrats’ message to Mai Khanh Tran was polite but unsparing. With half a dozen Democrats running for Congress in her Orange County district, they showed her a discouraging poll and argued that she could not win — and risked fracturing the party in the June primary election.

articles.headline: Scott Pruitt Before the E.P.A.: Fancy Homes, a Shell Company and Friends With Money
articles.snippet: The E.P.A. chief is under scrutiny for high spending and interactions with lobbyists. Many of the pitfalls he has encountered in Washington have echoes in his past.
articles.abstract: The E.P.A. chief is under scrutiny for high spending and interactions with lobbyists. Many of the pitfalls he has encountered in Washington have echoes in his past.
articles.lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — Early in Scott Pruitt’s political career, as a state senator from Tulsa, he attended a gathering at the Oklahoma City home of an influential telecommunications lobbyist who was nearing retirement and about to move away.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: As Rod Rosenstein Battles to Protect Mueller, His Tactics Could Cost the Justice Dept.
articles.snippet: Under siege by the president’s allies in the House, Mr. Rosenstein has acceded to some demands. But his allies worry that may expose the Justice Department to political meddling.
articles.abstract: Under siege by the president’s allies in the House, Mr. Rosenstein has acceded to some demands. But his allies worry that may expose the Justice Department to political meddling.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He has a reputation as a principled lawyer. He has worked for both Republican and Democratic attorneys general. He has a jugular instinct in courtroom battles but a distaste for political ones.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner, Sharon LaFraniere and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: What Does Kim Jong-un Want? U.S. Fears Answer Is ‘Give a Little, Gain a Lot’
articles.snippet: In Washington, most officials and experts believe that the North Korean leader is determined to cement his country’s status as a nuclear state while escaping the chokehold of economic sanctions.
articles.abstract: In Washington, most officials and experts believe that the North Korean leader is determined to cement his country’s status as a nuclear state while escaping the chokehold of economic sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As North Korea’s reclusive ruler, Kim Jong-un, prepares for a landmark meeting with President Trump, he has seized the diplomatic high ground, making conciliatory gestures on nuclear testing and American troops that have buoyed hopes in South Korea and won praise from Mr. Trump himself, who called it “big progress.”
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: A Shadowy War’s Newest Front: A Drone Base Rising From Saharan Dust
articles.snippet: Air Force personnel are working to complete a $110 million airfield that will be used to strike extremists in West and North Africa, a region where most Americans have no idea the country is fighting.
articles.abstract: Air Force personnel are working to complete a $110 million airfield that will be used to strike extremists in West and North Africa, a region where most Americans have no idea the country is fighting.
articles.lead_paragraph: AIR BASE 201, Niger — Rising from a barren stretch of African scrubland, a half-finished drone base represents the newest front line in America’s global shadow war.

articles.headline: As Another Pence Runs for Congress, His Business Record Raises Questions
articles.snippet: Greg Pence, the vice president’s brother, is mounting something of a stealth campaign, years after leading a chain that went bankrupt and being sued over personal debts.
articles.abstract: Greg Pence, the vice president’s brother, is mounting something of a stealth campaign, years after leading a chain that went bankrupt and being sued over personal debts.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ind. — When you have the best known name in your congressional district and your younger brother is a heartbeat away from the presidency, it is difficult to run a stealth campaign. But Greg Pence is doing a pretty good job of it.

articles.headline: Macron Takes a Risk in Courting Trump, but Has Little to Show for It
articles.snippet: The French president leaves on Monday for a state visit to Washington, where he will try, once again, to close the gap with President Trump on climate change, Iran and trade.
articles.abstract: The French president leaves on Monday for a state visit to Washington, where he will try, once again, to close the gap with President Trump on climate change, Iran and trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron was put on the spot this year in front of a room full of journalists when one asked, provocatively: Which man is more dangerous, North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un; or Donald J. Trump?
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Adam Nossiter

articles.headline: China, Feeling Left Out, Has Plenty to Worry About in North Korea-U.S. Talks
articles.snippet: Beijing fears that a grand deal with the North’s longtime enemies could diminish its influence over Pyongyang, experts said.
articles.abstract: Beijing fears that a grand deal with the North’s longtime enemies could diminish its influence over Pyongyang, experts said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, prepares for his meetings with the presidents of South Korea and the United States, China has found itself in an unaccustomed place: watching from the sidelines.

articles.headline: Tariff Dodgers Stand to Profit Off U.S.-China Trade Dispute
articles.snippet: Chinese brokers send goods around the world to disguise their origin and escape penalties. Tougher trade rules may end up only helping them.
articles.abstract: Chinese brokers send goods around the world to disguise their origin and escape penalties. Tougher trade rules may end up only helping them.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Want to avoid American tariffs? In China, a company called Settle Logistics says it knows a way.

articles.headline: Zelle, the Banks’ Answer to Venmo, Proves Vulnerable to Fraud
articles.snippet: The personal payment platform Zelle is flourishing. But so are fraudsters, who are exploiting weaknesses in the banks’ security.
articles.abstract: The personal payment platform Zelle is flourishing. But so are fraudsters, who are exploiting weaknesses in the banks’ security.
articles.lead_paragraph: Big banks are making it easy to zap money to your friends. Maybe too easy.

articles.headline: Amazon’s Critics Get New Life With Trump’s Attacks on the Company
articles.snippet: Many of Amazon’s opponents have struggled for years to be heard. Now they have the country’s most powerful bullhorn — President Trump — on their side.
articles.abstract: Many of Amazon’s opponents have struggled for years to be heard. Now they have the country’s most powerful bullhorn — President Trump — on their side.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of Amazon’s antagonists seized the moment last month with an unusual newspaper advertisement addressed to President Trump. The ad, from a nonprofit that advocates less government, attacked a Defense Department technology contract that Amazon intends to bid on, calling it a lucrative handout for the company.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang, Nick Wingfield and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: Public Servants Are Losing Their Foothold in the Middle Class
articles.snippet: Even as private employers have rebounded from the recession, the public sector’s ranks have withered, and pay and benefits have lagged.
articles.abstract: Even as private employers have rebounded from the recession, the public sector’s ranks have withered, and pay and benefits have lagged.
articles.lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — The anxiety and seething anger that followed the disappearance of middle-income jobs in factory towns has helped reshape the American political map and topple longstanding policies on tariffs and immigration.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Prominent Exit From Ad Industry Sets Off Questions About Future
articles.snippet: The resignation of WPP’s Martin Sorrell shocked the industry and also highlighted the question of what‘s next for advertising companies in a dynamic era.
articles.abstract: The resignation of WPP’s Martin Sorrell shocked the industry and also highlighted the question of what‘s next for advertising companies in a dynamic era.
articles.lead_paragraph: It came as a shock to Madison Avenue in the late 1980s when a British financial whiz named Martin Sorrell came for two pre-eminent American advertising agencies, embarking on hostile takeovers of J. Walter Thompson and the Ogilvy Group on his way to forging a global empire.

articles.headline: By Stifling Migration, Sudan’s Feared Secret Police Aid Europe
articles.snippet: Europe is outsourcing border management to distant countries, hoping to stop migrants before they cross the Mediterranean. But there may be a high moral cost.
articles.abstract: Europe is outsourcing border management to distant countries, hoping to stop migrants before they cross the Mediterranean. But there may be a high moral cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABU JAMAL, Sudan — At Sudan’s eastern border, Lt. Samih Omar led two patrol cars slowly over the rutted desert, past a cow’s carcass, before halting on the unmarked 2,000-mile route that thousands of East Africans follow each year in trying to reach the Mediterranean, and then onward to Europe.
